Jeff Nielsen wrote:
> 
> From: "J. B. Rainsberger" wrote
>  >
>  > mark_lybarger wrote:
>  >>
>  >>
>  >> i'm looking for arguments for and against keeping junit test classes
>  >> outside if the projects main source tree.  maybe this could be a pole,
>  >> but i'm after the arguments more than what everyone actually is doing.
>  >
>  > Separate source trees makes it easier to ship the production code
>  > without the test code.
>  >
>  > Separate source trees reduces the likelihood of accidentally having
>  > production code depend on test code: I can build the production code
>  > without the test code and see compile errors right away.
>  >
>  > Separate source trees makes it easier to identify test code and
>  > production code in a simple directory listing.
>  >
>  > Of these, only #2 is not solved by better tools.
> 
> Here's some reasons *for* keeping the tests in the same tree.
> 
> - Everyone on the team--no matter what their IDE or setup--can find the
> tests since they're in the same directory.  If you use a naming convention
> of ClassNameTest, then the test classes alphabetize right next to (or at
> least near) the classes they test

There is an underlying assumption here of one-to-one correspondence 
between production classes and test classes. In many cases, this is 
neither desired nor recommended.

The other points are well made, which is why I made my comment about 
"better tools".
